questions.question: The car is difficult to …………………… at high speeds.
He looks ………………………
questions.description: Look is a copular verb. We use adjectives, not adverbs, to modify copular verbs.

questions.question: She fell ………………………….. on the floor.
questions.description: We often use adjectives after descriptions with sit, stand, lie and fall.

questions.question: The situation seemed ……………………............
questions.description: Seem is a copular verb. We use adjectives to modify copular verbs.

questions.question: She sat ………………………...., waiting for their decision.
questions.description: We often use adjectives after descriptions with sit, stand, lie and fall.

questions.question: She is a woman who …………………….. to say what she thinks.
questions.description: When dare is used as an ordinary verb, it is followed by an infinitive with to.

questions.question: The old woman ………………………….. to open the door.
questions.description: The ordinary form of dare is common in negative sentences.

questions.question: It was ………………………. a meeting than a party.
questions.description: We can use more of before a singular countable noun. This is common in modifying descriptions.

questions.question: You put ……………………….. too much salt in the soup.
questions.description: We can use much to modify too much.

questions.question: You made ………………………. a lot of mistakes.
questions.description: A lot can be modified by quite or rather.

questions.question: We drove ……………………….. up to Madrid in four hours.
questions.description: Before prepositions referring to movement, right can mean completely or exactly.
